reviewText:
Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 has already shipped and millions of eager fans are already playing. By now you already know whether or not you are going to be getting this game, which makes this review rather pointless. What can I possibly say that you haven't already heard; what tidbit of exclusive information can I pass on that you already don't know. It's not like Activision has been keeping their games a secret. I guess all that's left for me to do is share my personal experience with the game, what the designers did right, what they did wrong, and let the chips falls where they may.

There are so many Call of Duty installments out there it's hard to keep them straight when it comes to the story. Modern Warfare 3 is the direct sequel to Modern Warfare 2, which was the direct sequel to the original Modern Warfare, so in essence, this is the third installment in the trilogy. We have our familiar cast of characters, Soap, Price, and Nickolai, and a new recruit, Yuri, the Russian member of your team who will be at the other end of your controls for most of the missions. Makarov is still up to his old tricks in his quest for global domination. After his failed attempt in Modern Warfare 2, Makarov has basically initiated WWIII with an assault on the USA as well as a massive simultaneous terrorist strike using bio-weapons.

Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 assaults you with its overpowering presentation, from the opening moment where your Humvee is taken out by an RPG in NYC and a building explodes and comes raining down on you until the bittersweet final boss encounter. Despite its aging graphics engine, the game maintains a fluid 60fps while pumping out graphics that are easily on par with Battlefield 3. Some scenes border on photorealistic, and when you set the entire thing in motion with sweeping cinematic camera moves things get real crazy real fast. The level of complexity in the level design and the amount of detail is staggering and surprisingly, especially in the multiplayer maps, and it only gets better on the PC.

The sound mix is completely immersive with a stirring soundtrack that will fuel your adrenalin, great voice acting and in-game chatter, and some fantastic sound effects for all the weapons and explosions. The sampling rate has been boosted so these guns have never sounded better or more realistic, and there are plenty of shellshock and disorientation effects that will leave you breathless. Sadly, the whole presentation falls a bit short of console greatness since I'm not playing on a home theater, but with a good set of speakers or surround headphones, Modern Warfare 3 will still blow you away - just not as much.

The game kicks off in New York City and thanks to pre-release coverage, you've probably already seen most of the first two chapters that has you destroying an enemy jamming tower then heading out into the harbor to cripple a Russian sub and launch its missiles on its own fleet. From there you'll need to rescue Soap from a safe house, then protect the Russian president and his daughter in one of my favorite levels that had me feeling like Harrison Ford in Air Force One. Then it's off to Sierra Leone, London, Somali, Paris, and Berlin as you try to foil Makarovs plans for world supremacy.

Without a doubt, this is the best story in the trilogy, with each mission feeding into the next or at least having some parallel story thread. There are no missions stuck in there just because they are cool"

As someone who has played every single Call of Duty game aside from Call of Duty 2 and the new Advanced Warfare. Modern Warfare 3 was something I looked forward too but I had hear bad things about it. So I waited a few years and actually played in this order COD1,UO,WAW,4,BlackOps,MW2,Ghosts,BlackOps2,and finally MW3. I used to hate Call of Duty and it took me a while to distinguish the enjoyment of the singleplayer experiance from the twitch shooter that is the repetitive multiplayer that has really not changed since COD1, if anything it has lost amazing game modes (BehindEnemyLines,BaseAssault). When Bad Company 2 came out I basically said the hell with COD, BUT I came back to the franchise for what it does right, the enjoyable rollercoster that is the playable movie of the Campaign. I loved the story in ModernWarfare and the trilogy is pretty well wrapped up with MW3. A lot of questions about the story are answered if the ending itself is a little lackluster for all the work you have gone through in the previous games to get to the ultimate showdown of two dewds. Anyway no spoilers but the campaign was pretty well paced and enjoyable with some great set peices and the feel of WW3 was captured as well as this old engine can capture.

I would not recommend this game to anyone to start with, nor if you are not invested into the ModernWarfare trilogy story etc. For fans of the series though its a must, to bring the story arc to a rather thrilling conclusion. I still think the Black Ops games have been the best COD games since COD united Offensive and the original MW.

Hope this helps you guys. It gets a cautious recommend from me for fans of the franchise and story.

reviewText:
Single-player: Except for the weird prologue, I thought that the story was a ton of fun. If it gets boring, pick a harder difficulty (and have fun dying if you picked one too hard). The fact that each mission isn't totally reset when you die is a lovely perk that (while I should have expected, I didn't) made the game much more enjoyable. The special ops missions are a lot of fun, but a few things should be pointed out:
1). It can take a while to find people to play with, so if you don't have patience, bring friends.
2). You can't play cross - server special ops with your friends, so if you have a Mac and your friends have Windows, you're out of luck.
3). If you do have a Mac ( and Windows - loving friends), play multi - player

Multi - Player: A ton of fun to play once you can participate in the games in any meaningful amount (meaning that you don't get killed every time you poke your head out of the hole you're hiding in). However, a few tips:
1). There aren't any set noob maps, so if you're new, this can be frustrating. But, if I made it (and I sucked a TON at first), you can make it (unless you suck more than I did).
2). There aren't any rooftop vantages or upper floor rooms that are protected to the point when sniping becomes a good option for new players. (Some maps don't have ANY  very elevated sniping spots) You have to be good (i would hesitantly say VERY good) in order to run and gun with a sniper, so avoid this unless you have a lot of practice in the single - player (harder difficulties) or in other games
3). Many of the game modes don't have anyone playing them. The two that i've found to be most frequented by players are Team Deathmatch and Kill Confirmed. Others are played, of course, but it will be harder to find a full room.
4). As always, playing with friends is a ton of fun, and if some of them are experienced, all the better. If you don't have friends, quit playing games and find some :). JK. I don't have friends either.

A fun game in the FPS category, and I had a lot of fun playing. However, patience and time are necessary for the full experience. Despite the restrictions at first, the hackers (there weren't that many, actually, but they were annoying), and the limited gamemodes, I enjoyed my time, so I'll give this a (7/10).

Actually, on second thought, I've remembered how much fun I had playing hide and seek with a bunch of guys (armed with Five - Sevens), playing arrow - chicken with C4 and Frag Grenades, and amusing my friends by making ridiculously macho comments, then dying a second later by more attentive players. So, I'll give it an 8/10.

Always remember: If at first you don't succeed, you probably never will. Give up now and save yourself some trouble :).

Modern Warfare 3 picks up where Modern Warfare 2 left off. I mean, exactly where it left off. Russia is at war with America, Makarov is at large, Soap's injured, and everything is blowing up. If you didn't play Modern Warfare 2, which served as a decent starting point and didn't require the first game to understand it, you won't have any idea about what's going on, and the game doesn't do much to get you up to date. It feels very much like the third movie in a trilogy, and the second movie ended on a cliffhanger.

The gameplay, both in single player and multiplayer modes, is identical to that of Modern Warfare 2. You can carry two weapons and two types of grenades (one offensive, one special) at one time and you have to hide behind cover and employ tactical savvy in your approach firefights if you want to kill your enemies. reviewText:
The Modern Warfare series' finale.

Back in November 2011, I told myself I wouldn't get this game. I was upset with Activision that Infinity Ward was no longer Infinity Ward, I thought the game is going to suck and I didn't want to play a Call of Duty game ever again. Or something along the lines of that. But in the end, I did give in to the hype and got it.

It might have been caused by my low expectations, but I enjoyed the campaign a lot. It didn't suck, it didn't feel like an utter waste of time, it didn't scream 'throw me into the trash bin.' It felt like a proper Call of Duty title, with all of your explosions, plot twists and emotions included. I don't think I would recommend it to anyone who hasn't played the two previous Modern Warfare games yet, because it jumps straight in where its predecessor ended which could obviously leave you not knowing what's really going on, but everyone else - yeah, the campaign is solid. And also a trip all around the world.

The multiplayer feels, well, revised. Much more balanced in terms of killstreak (or pointstreak, in Modern Warfare 3's case) rewards, overpowered explosives, perks and all that stuff, though not so much in the guns section as weapons like the MP7 or ACR are clearly better than the others. It's not a deal-breaker, though - the game is enjoyable, and there are some cool new things like the Kill Confirmed game mode or the already mentioned pointstreak rewards system which divides them into three categories, allowing you to even get some defensive & support ones without your points resetting on death. The maps are good as well as usual in Call of Duty.

The last thing I definitely have to mention (and recommend) is the new Survival mode, which allows you to - either alone or with a bunch of friends - try and survive against waves of enemies, similar to the Zombies mode in Treyarch's iterations of the series. It's fun to just jump in and mess around.

All in all, Modern Warfare 3 is a good game.

reviewText:
This is an old game, but still one of the best in the series. Along with the two previous Modern Warfare titles, arguably the pinnacle of the Call of Duty series.

In no particular order, some of the stand-out points:

Outstanding sound design: explosions and guns feel like the real thing, something later titles in the series have lost.
Superbly paced campaign [for maximum value/enjoyment, play the previous titles first]
Variety in terms of roles within the campaign setting, and also in terms of locale.
Spec Ops! Something I wish later titles would bring back. So much fun when played in co-op.
Survival is also a lot of fun (wave based survival game).
Awesome multiplayer (great hit detection, excellent maps, decent weapon variety, solid look and feel to weapons)
That being said... there are some issues. A lack of dedicated servers can mean extreme P2P lag, and unfortunately the multiplayer is rife with hackers :/ it really does take all the fun out of it.

If you enjoy Survival and Spec Ops modes, I would suggest buying the DLC packs as well, since they add missions and game modes on top of the already impressive package.

Overall, highly recommended. I love this game <3

reviewText:
This was one of the last decent Call Of Duties before they took off (Literally) with the jump packs and Halo jumping nonsense. To me this is a real Call Of Duty and it plays exactly how an arcade shooter should in most ways. This is the last COD with pro perks, a feature that they removed for unknown reasons. Probably because players are too lazy to shoot down 40 killstreaks or destroy 50 enemy equipments (Lazy buggers).

The guns in the game aren't at all balanced, but that's what makes it fun, how you ask? Well I will tell you how. There's nothing more satisfying than dropping a M.O.A.B against a full party of MP7/ACR using tryhards with an underpowered weapon. Recoil isn't really a problem on this game, 1 or 2 guns present a mini challenge but anyone with a brain knows how to pull down slightly with the mouse.

The 3 killstreak options made this game very fresh and added numerous different playstyles to the game. The noobs get rewarded even if they die if they opt for the support package. Moab hunters get rewarded when using the specialist package. And the diehard MW2 fans get rewarded for using the Assault package. The killstreaks aren't that powerful in the assault package, nowhere near as good as MW2 but it can still be fun to use from time to time.
Most of the maps on Modern Warfare 3 have decent design and stick to the same formula that was used on Modern Warfare 2. They promote rushing and movement most of the time and they try to stay small so you won't be caught looking for a gunfight for too long (Unlike Ghosts. Yuck). However, some players still insist on using Thermal LMGs in the most annoying ways. There are quite a few clans that scour TDM using this strategy. LMGs combined with a campy playstyle is almost impossible to beat considering they're deadly accurate with thermal. I would personally consider them to be overpowered. Almost everything has some sort of counter-play, minus the C4. If you have blast shield on and it's right next to you. You're dead, no questions asked, same thing with claymores and Bouncing betties. Your only saviour is a ballistic vest and this means you will have to play using the support package which is heavily looked down upon by most players.

Quickscopers and proper snipers are a pain on this game yes, but you will find yourself surviving a shot from them quite often (If you really hate them, ballistic vests make sure you're always a 2 hit kill, even to the head!) however, a decent quickscoper can outclass any gun at any range and it makes things quite unfair. Quickscopers can easily outclass a shotgunner/SMG at close range which never makes any sense, but then again there are tonnes of things which don't make sense in COD, like another age old problem of shooting first, hitting them a tonne and somehow dying first? That's the problem with the extremely low tickrate that COD has. If we could have a tickrate above 100 then things would improve drastically. Or would they?

The online support for this game is where things begin to go sour very quickly. Hackers are allowed to roam free and there are some days where you begin to forget what a normal lobby even looks like. You can run into the same hacker for months on end and report him everytime and nothing will be done, the report button is like the pointless button from ASDF movie. If you leave say a TDM lobby and go back to search for a TDM lobby, you will often find yourself back in the exact same lobby, this is another frustrating feature. Also there's the age old problem of joining a game where your team is losing by 60 kills and there's no way you will win and it goes against your Win loss ratio. Many players take pride in their W/L but most of the time there's nothing you can do to save it.

Kicktool abusers are exactly what this game doesn't need and they're everywhere! This tool was released so the MW3 community could combat hackers by kicking them, but now it's used by good/bad players to kick decent players from the lobby so it's easy for them. Bad players end up thinking everyone who kills them has some sort of hack because of their God complex. Whilst the good players (With the hacktool) have no honour and kick the other good players as soon as they see their KD in danger.
To conclude my review, I must admit that this game has been a lot of fun over the years and was definitely worth the £30 I spent back in the day on it. But it's not worth that now at all. The DLC is dead, half the multiplayer modes are empty, and the player base is dwindling. You will be lucky to reach above 100 hours before growing to hate the game and quitting it, never looking back again. Rightly so, Activision and co never continue supporting their older games and that's their downfall, it's sad but unfortunately it's a way of life. Why generate a loss by appeasing the players that remain on the old CODs when you can 'appease' the players on the newer CODs and continue generating revenue? I digress, time for the ratings out of ten.

Multiplayer: 6/10 - It's broken and there's no denying that.

Campaign : 7/10 - It kept to the MW formula that made the other MW games fun.

Special ops/survival etc : 5/10 - I found myself getting bored instantly with both Spec ops and survival. They effectively copied MW2s spec ops, just badly.

Overall: 6.5/10 - This is a very fun game If you can look past all the hackers, kick tool abusers, campers, overpowered weapon abusers and headglitchers. It still isn't worth the price tag however. £20 sounds more reasonable.
Thanks for reading.

An Epic conclusion to the Epic Saga!

The modern Warfare series has come a long way ever since the first modern warfare released in 2006. It has evolutionized the genre and changed the way we play and think of FPS games. Althought, the game adds nothing new to the already complex formula, it does adds smoothness to the game core mechanics and the fast paced arcade-style shooter, ranking & rewarding as well as unique kill streak system in which skillful players shall go on a rampage quite easily with the aid of air supports or ground fire powers.

The thrid entry to the series does not dissappoint because the single player campaign is filled with action as well as intense sequences. The story mode does not have a good replayability unless you are a collection fanatic that will be interested in perfecting the game with enemy intels, other wise I'd say it is not worth the hassle.

The music score is an honorable mention here as the composer Brian Tayler has really hit the score with the music on the battlefield as well as the impact of guns and bullets hitting different places. The sound track is overall excellent not only does it set a atmospherical environment but it also connects the emotional link between the players and the characters and maintaining this link is what gives us the reason to care about the characters.

In terms of multiplayer, the same formula applies. It is still addictive and still fun as new weapons and maps being added but the only down side to that is that additional DLCs will cost a fortune.

Overall I will recommend this game to all FPS lovers and action gamers in general.

The only reason I own this game is that I got it as a gift from someone else.

Now, had COD4 and MW2 not already existed, I might be a little more enthusiastic about this game. I will admit that despite the blatant rehashing of MW2 assets (models, textures, even the bloody HUD), the campaign was entertaining enough to keep me going from start to finish. Soap and Price are both badasses. The scripted destruction events are admittedly well done and immersive. The weapons pack a lot of punch and feel satisfying to use. The plot, while predictable, is sufficiently intriguing and isn't riddled with cheesy dialogue. Unfortunately, the multiplayer, which was what kept me coming back to previous COD games, proved to be the same letdown that MW2 was.

No dedicated servers if you want a ranked game. On a PC platform where latency is very noticeable thanks to everyone using a hyper-responsive keyboard and mouse, this is unacceptable. If everyone's connection is decent, then the experience is tolerable but still inferior to that of a dedicated server. Especially when a game supports up to 18 players, who don't necessarily all live in the same geographic region. It's most annoying when host migration occurs due to someone ragequitting or just experiencing an Internet blackout. There's a reason why even some co-op games like Left 4 Dead use dedicated servers despite the considerably lower player count - the performance is just so much better that way!

reviewText:
Two years ago, I wrote a quick review. Now, I want to expand it.

Modern Warfare 3 takes where the previous game left you. Soap, the hero of Modern Warfare and the captain of the former Team 141, is badly wounded. Price and him escape thanks to Nikolai but you're followed by the fanatics under Makarov's order. Makarov? He's a mad Russian terrorist, an ultra-nationalist that attacked his own people in an airport to trigger a war against USA - though Shepherd, the general commanding Soap's unit isn't really a stranger to that. Anyway, after Shepherd's betrayal and death, Price and Soap are considered as war criminals. But it doesn't mean that they're going to stay without searching to clear their name. They're helped by Yuri, a man that hates Makarov with a passion. And during that time, Frost, a US soldier, will also participate to the battles of his life in USA and Europe....

To understand the settings of Modern Warfare, it's strongly recommended to play Modern Warfare and Modern Warfare 2 as you'll find characters appearing in all these games. Or also just to understand the background.

Modern Warfare 3 will make you play Soap, though briefly, Yuri, the Russian that will follow Price and Soap into their missions, Frost, battling against Russians in USA and Europe and under Sandman's command - Sandman being an ancient member of Team 141, Harkov, a Russian bodyguard for the President, Burns, a SAS member pursuing terrorists in London and Price for the last mission of Modern Warfare.

As usual, the goal is to make sure your objectives are done, without being killed (you don't have an health meter, so the only way to survive is to retreat and let the screen coming back to normal), with  people to protect. You're not alone, you always have friends with you (Soap and Price when you're Yuri, Sandman and his squad when you're Frost, etc..).

True, it's a Call of Duty, so don't expect anything making a full use of your brain (only when you need not to be spotted). And I still don't like a too nervous gameplay but you're getting used to it. Though good luck in Veteran...

However, the places you're visiting are really great: from Paris to Berlin by New York or Siberia...

A Call of Duty wouldn't be a Call of Duty if you don't loose some teammates or get your own character killed (will you be surprised that Makarov is also behind some kills?). The most shocking death will surprise you because you never thought that he would be killed off. Call of Duty, it's like the Walking Dead (the comic) or Games of Throne: you never know who will be killed or spared.

The graphics are marvelous. The music is badass.

And you still have the mode where you can play alone or with a friend.

Modern Warfare 3 is really a good Call of Duty. Not really innovating, but the war seen by different points of view, knowing that each mission is tied to the previous one (ex: Price, Soap and Yuri got information, they've relayed it to the right people and Sandman and his squads are assigned on a mission based on that intel).

Oh yeah, the multiplayer? I don't play. No way. The CoD community is too... competitive to my tastes.

Go ahead, you can buy it eyes closed.... if you own MW and MW2. Else you will never understand the universe unless you read all the facts on the wiki.

This would not be that much of a problem, as even some of the best titles in the series (CoD4, CoD2) don't have the most complex storylines, but in this  game it feels like the developpers first thought of what cool set piece they should introduce and built around that, when they should've made something more contextually appropriate (the example closest to mind is the mission where you use an armed ROV to effortlessly destroy the enemy). Most of the gimmicks that you see in singleplayer are put there because Sledgehammer Games wanted to justify various killstreaks that you can use in multiplayer. Despite all this, there is one small flash of brilliance in the campaign of MW3 and that is its ending mission. While it may not be amongst the most memorable in the series (Hill 400 in CoD2, Heat in CoD4, Vendetta and the final mission in CoD WaW), it certainly stands on its own as a fairly satisfying conclusion to the Modern Warfare series and it is quite a fun ride.\nMoving on, let's talk about the multiplayer which is mostly a mix of good and bad. One major complaint I have with the game is the levels on weapons and the need to earn XP for each weapon in order to unlock Proficiencies and attachments for it. This is a step in the complete wrong direction, even after Treyarch nailed it with the ability to buy which attachment or camo you want. Furthermore, the Proficiencies you can unlock for each weapon create massive disparities between newer and older players. This is most visible when using shotguns which have 2 Proficiencies that are vital: Range and Damage. Both of these are gained at  the last levels of the weapon, a decision I find most absurd. You will have to play most of your first 40 levels without them, which makes it really hard for you to perform with shotguns, especially the weaker AA-12. To make things worse, deathstreaks have returned, worse than ever, there even being a killstreak that shows you were your killer is. However, there were quite a few innovations" introduced

A highly satisfying finale to a breathtaking series. Set in an authentic, believable environment, Modern Warfare 3 brings to bear open armed conflict in real life locales like never before. The streets, buildings, posters and magazines in the local vendors bring a new degree of realism to the monitor. The weapon effects are superb and the stealth is highly suspenseful.

The group dynamics are nigh on perfect. Each squad member coordinates expertely with the other and if you follow their lead and pick off enemies as they do, you can be a valuable member of the team. The enemy AI is challenging and will give you a hard time if you let them take cover and spread their numbers. Fortunately, your own and the advanced weapons at your disposal help even the odds nicely.

Modern Warfare polishes the game engine in all the right places and heightens the tension with expertly written sudden events that can lead to your death if you fail to act quickly enough. In story this installment helps to finally put an end to the Russian threat once and for all in a very satisfying manner. It can be tough, especially for those who are new to squad shooters, but to play the game and finish it is a very worthwhile and rewarding experience.

Derided by some and often touted as a Modern Warfare 2 clone, Modern Warfare 3 is actually a very good cap off to a fantastic series. There's nothing cloneworthy about this entry in the Call of Duty franchise as you fight back the Russian invasion in the United States and slog through varied environments with Price and Soap while you hunt for Makarov across the globe. The visuals are crisp enough and the atmosphere matches the tone and pace of the game perfectly. It feels like a world on the brink of annihilation. The audio adds to the feelings. From the guns firing to ambient effects all the way through the voice acting, it is superb and reflects well upon the art direction of the game.

The story, for me, was an incredible finish to a powerful story arc. From the battles in New York and Germany to the slog through Africa and the backalleys of Prague, the story is fast and powerful. The turn in Prague is especially gripping as two of my favorite characters, Soap and Kamarov, meet savage ends. It was at that moment I kept playing until I finished the campaign and killed Makarov. The decision to kill two key characters from MW and MW2 was powerful and gave me a sense of urgency to find the man responsible. Never have I felt such satisfaction from finishing a villain. The only other villian that gave me that much enjoyment from finally killing was Jack from Borderlands 2. Truly, the story board direction was top notch and I give them high praise for giving us a gripping, powerful and semi-cinematic experience to enjoy.

However, I know everyone loves the multiplayer more than the story. Even in this department, there's no shortage of things to do. While nearly MW2 2.0, there's enough differences in perks, weapons and equipment to keep from being too stale. Thankfully, silliness like Danger Close and Stopping Power did not make a resurgence in this iteration. Overall, I've enjoyed the MW3 multiplayer more than MW2. There's more modes and arguably better balance.

I fully recommend this title. If you play for the story, make sure you play Modern Warfare 1 and 2 so you're up to speed. For you multiplayer fans looking for a fast, furious game, this will not disappoint.

The modern Warfare series has come a long way ever since the first modern warfare released in 2006. It has evolutionized the genre and changed the way we play and think of FPS games. Althought, the game adds nothing new to the already complex formula, it does adds smoothness to the game core mechanics and the fast paced arcade-style shooter, ranking & rewarding as well as unique kill streak system in which skillful players shall go on a rampage quite easily with the aid of air supports or ground fire powers.

The thrid entry to the series does not dissappoint because the single player campaign is filled with action as well as intense sequences. Derided by some and often touted as a Modern Warfare 2 clone, Modern Warfare 3 is actually a very good cap off to a fantastic series. There's nothing cloneworthy about this entry in the Call of Duty franchise as you fight back the Russian invasion in the United States and slog through varied environments with Price and Soap while you hunt for Makarov across the globe. The visuals are crisp enough and the atmosphere matches the tone and pace of the game perfectly. It feels like a world on the brink of annihilation. The audio adds to the feelings. From the guns firing to ambient effects all the way through the voice acting, it is superb and reflects well upon the art direction of the game.

The story, for me, was an incredible finish to a powerful story arc. From the battles in New York and Germany to the slog through Africa and the backalleys of Prague, the story is fast and powerful. The turn in Prague is especially gripping as two of my favorite characters, Soap and Kamarov, meet savage ends. It was at that moment I kept playing until I finished the campaign and killed Makarov. The decision to kill two key characters from MW and MW2 was powerful and gave me a sense of urgency to find the man responsible. Never have I felt such satisfaction from finishing a villain. The only other villian that gave me that much enjoyment from finally killing was Jack from Borderlands 2. Truly, the story board direction was top notch and I give them high praise for giving us a gripping, powerful and semi-cinematic experience to enjoy.

However, I know everyone loves the multiplayer more than the story. Even in this department, there's no shortage of things to do. While nearly MW2 2.0, there's enough differences in perks, weapons and equipment to keep from being too stale. Thankfully, silliness like Danger Close and Stopping Power did not make a resurgence in this iteration. Overall, I've enjoyed the MW3 multiplayer more than MW2. There's more modes and arguably better balance.

I fully recommend this title. If you play for the story, make sure you play Modern Warfare 1 and 2 so you're up to speed. For you multiplayer fans looking for a fast, furious game, this will not disappoint.

DROPZONE
n Drop Zone, two teams must fight over a moving location on the map (marked with Care Package Marker smoke) to gain points. It differentiates itself from an ordinary King of the Hill gametype, however, with the addition of Care Packages as a reward for successfully holding on to the point. Approximately every 15 seconds a team holds a zone, a Care Package, an Airdrop Trap (in MW3), an Emergency Airdrop (notably NOT normally available under other circumstances), or a Juggernaut/Juggernaut Recon delivered via C-130 will be called automatically on the drop zone. To win, either one team must reach the score limit, or else the victor is determined by who has the most points when time is up.

INFECTED
The game starts with all players being survivors. In the upper left hand corner of the screen, there is a timer that starts with nine seconds counting down to the Infected. After the nine seconds, one player is randomly chosen to be first infected.  The survivors are the players who are not infected, hence the name Survivors". The surviving players must hide from and kill the Infected to try and survive until time runs out; each game lasts five minutes. The Survivors spawn with an unknown weapon (depending on what the custom settings are) and must survive by killing the Infected or hiding. 50 points are given to Survivors every time a Survivor is Infected. The name given with the points is "Survivor". The round ends when either the last Survivor is killed/infected

I have played the entirety of the Modern Warfare series a good 5 times over. A good 1000+ hours spend on Modern Warfare, 400+ spent on Modern Warfare 2, and under 50 hours on Modern Warfare 3. I played competitively in multiplayer for both Modern Warfare and Modern Warfare 2, but not the 3rd installment, with good reason. The quality of the game slowly degrades between these installments. Surprisingly to me, the average consumer doesn't seem to notice the changes in game mechanics througout the series. Regardless, I have a few points to make about this series in this review.

In the past week, I played through the entire campaigns of MW, MW2 and MW3 on Veteran difficulty. The first impression that comes to mind is this: the most difficult of the 3, on the highest difficulty possible, is MW. MW also happens to have the most compelling story line, as well as the most difficult mission: the flashback mission of Price and MacMillan in Chernobyl. Hands down, with my rather diverse and expansive gaming experience, my favorite mission/scene/short-story of any game, of all time. *Spoiler here* I am still upset that Soap died near the end of this game. No one likes Yuri until the very last scene of the game as there is absolutely zero characterization for him when introduced. Also...isn't it a little redundant to have Soap almost killed once and then killed the next time? I feel like he would be a bit more cautious even ini the chaos of a war-zone.

Graphically speaking, MW was not a beautiful game...but it was certainly well put together- especially for 2007. MW2 in the same regard, was stunning. The game looked amazing- and it still does in all aspects. MW3, however, is a little different. In the opening sequence of the campaign, images are displayed on broken shards of glass, and it has the potential to look really cool. Although, even running this game with the highest quality settings possible- on a gaming-specific rig- it looks pixelated and rather horrible, even.

Now for gameplay mechanics. MW reminds me a lot of Counter Strike: Source and Global Offensive in many ways. The controls are very ridig, snap-to, and reaction based. The weapon-balancing *still* needs work as grenades (although realistically...) seem to end all life in sight. The killstreaks are solid and default for everyone, and PC maps like Killzone compensates for the shortcomings of default killstreaks making matches run long. MW2 is similar, but a lot more smooth. Going prone doesn't sound like you dropped a tank on the ground, and aiming down the sights allowed you more freedom to ADS in the dark (while scope was black) and adjust based on a gut feeling. In single player, MW2 only had one or two flaws. Certain areas where one would get stuck if you jumped on top of, but nothing that was glaringly annoying. MW3 is much different. It feels like a cartoon. If you sit and shoot nothing, zero enemies are shot- even when you have two tanks with you and the entire Metal" squad by your side. Very unlikely. Also: it is *very* important to note the following: comparing the 3 MW games side by side by side...MW3 Veteran difficulty is very easy. I don't understand why. It seems to take merely 2 bullets- shot at anyone
date: anywhere- to take down an enemy. It also seems as though the missions as the British SAS in the middle of MW3's campaign make the mechanics even more odd. You have much less HP than other parts of the game (of course excluding the beginning of the last mission in juggernaut suits). You die much more easily

reviewText: Awesome

Another return to the great COD franchise before Treyarch took over.

Although Sledgehammer games took over after Infinity Ward got shafted, this game I feel best mirrors the previous greatest iteration of the COD franchise which was CODMW2.
Not a fan of Advanced Warfare or Black Ops, but of this game yes.

Looking for the game closes to the previous Call of Duty Modern Warfare 2? This is it.

Trademark blockbuster explosions and action? Check.
Trademark graphics? Check.
Symphonic score and full orchestra to accompany explosions? Check.
No silly spacesuits, jumpsuits or gravity guns? Check.
Missions take place in a variety of locations, from Sierra Leone to the UK.

Notable missions include:
-  playing SAS at the warehouse. Love those hammy British accents and LIttle Bird Helicopters.
-  Operating the Hind remote machine gun.
-  fighting through Paris
-  calling in artillery strikes with purple smoke
-  operating the AC-130 Gunship in Paris

The Special Ops section is where things get stupid fast.

The Solo survival missions are beyond dumb. The AI are bullet sponges and you barely have enough time to buy new weapons and ammo. It gets boring fast.

Playing Advanced Warfare for me meant a big break from what COD meant. Not a fan of the newer releases which are too tech-oriented and futuristic.

The campaign is a bit short but given teh amount of explosions, battles, cinematic cut scenes is well worth it, but only if you manage to buy it elsewhere on sale.

Modern Warfare 3 is the last Great installment in the COD franchise. The multiplayer is very well balanced. I know this to be true as i checked some steam accounts and found them to be banned along with the fact that there was no more activity in the game. The game has been out for a long time but has many many players still. It is second place in players in the COD franchise.

Single Player

Story is very good continuing in the MW series of the story. I would have to say that my favorite storyline in the MW series was COD 4: Modern Warfare. But the story in this installment is still very good.

I have over 800 hours in this game and i still play it. It is fun and if you have not purchased it you are really missing out :-)

reviewText:
I've bought this game in the U.S. when I was on a trip there. It was on discount (now Iknow why). I usually start playing in multiplayer mode after I finished the campaign, so my article is mostly about the multiplayer experience. Let's see the Pros:
-Call of Duty game
-Lots of weapons
-Usual Call of Duty graphics
-good Single player campaign story (at last they've finished it!)

And now let's see the Cons:
-the worst Call of Duty Multiplayer game I've ever played (played almost all the episodes)
-You will be angry even before the match starts
-Lot of connection problems (If you've played even 10 minutes with it, you understand what I'm saying)
-Annoying Kill Streak rewards
-Lots of campers and kids who don't even know what this game is about
-lots of people who can't play and start cheating, ruining all the game and fun of others.
-at least 10 game modes (but 99% of MW3 players use the standard TDM...)
-If you don't have at least a 1 Gbps Internet connection, don't even try it!
-Lot of DLC-s which would be essential if you want to play (these costs about 3 times the price of the game)

I think that's all I can say about it. I spent many hours trying to find what's good in this game, but in the end, I always quit with the anger and the dissapointment with the question in my mind: Why the hell did i just buy this? (the answer is: franchise advertising). People nowadays (unfortunately me too) only looks at a cover, or advertising, and if the name is familiar, we go and buy it. We shouldn't!
